title: Boston police now required to wear nametags under new contract extension
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston police patrol officers are now required to wear nametags under a new contract extension with the city.
The contract extension with the Boston Police Patrolmen’s Association includes wage increases and a more thorough officer evaluation system.
Mayor Michelle Wu emphasizes the importance of transparency in policing and contrasts BPD's approach with federal immigration enforcement tactics.

title: The backlash has arrived: 6 takeaways from a good night for Democrats
author: Reid J. Epstein, The New York Times
bullets: Democrats win statewide elections in Virginia, New Jersey, California, and Pennsylvania, rebuking Trump's policies and impacting Republican seats.
Zohran Mamdani becomes NYC mayor-elect, representing a progressive shift for Democrats, defeating ex-Gov. Andrew Cuomo.
California voters approve a measure to redraw congressional districts, aiding Democrats in upcoming midterms amid Newsom's campaign.

title: The Swedish candy craze has taken Boston by storm. Here’s where you can get it.
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Swedish candy gains popularity in Boston following a viral TikTok, leading to increased sales at pick-and-mix stores.
Madeleine's Candy Shop, The Sweetish Fish, and lil sweet treat in Boston offer various Swedish candies to meet demand.
Swedish candy is noted for being healthier than American candy, lacking gluten, corn syrup, or trans fat.

title: Few answers as Woburn-based Newpro files for bankruptcy after sudden shutdown
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Newpro, a Woburn-based home improvement firm, shut down abruptly on October 28, 2025, surprising employees and customers.
The company and its parent, Renovo Home Partners, filed for bankruptcy, affecting over 10 subsidiaries and nationwide stakeholders.
Newpro, founded in 1945 and acquired by Renovo in 2022, did not provide a reason for closure, leaving projects uncertain.

title: Snag 20% off JetBlue flights in December during this limited-time sale
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: JetBlue is offering a 20% discount on flights for travel between Dec. 2-18 during a two-day sale ending Nov. 6.
The sale excludes Friday and Sunday travel, applies to nonstop base fares, and requires the promo code TAKE20 on jetblue.com.
Additional discounts up to 40% are available for round-trip bookings in vacation packages for travel through March 31, 2026.

title: WWII veteran’s remains are being returned to Weymouth
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Private Alfred Langevin's remains are returning to Weymouth after being identified 81 years post his disappearance in WWII.
Langevin vanished in 1944 during the Battle of Hürtgen Forest; his remains were found in 1946 but identified in 2025.
A procession and burial with military honors are planned in Weymouth, with public viewing at Town Hall on Sunday.

title: Embattled Everett mayor loses reelection bid to city councilor
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Everett City Councilor Robert Van Campen defeated Mayor Carlo DeMaria by over 600 votes, ending DeMaria's 18-year tenure.
Van Campen campaigned on accountability, transparency, and addressing issues like school overcrowding and traffic congestion.
Mayor Carlo DeMaria faced scrutiny for $180,000 in questionable payments and previous sexual harassment allegations.

title: ‘The sun is up and we’re fighting’: Bill O’Brien’s fiery response to question about Boston College football
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Bill O'Brien defended Boston College football despite team’s 1-8 record, expressing optimism and commitment to continue competing.
O'Brien responded strongly to a question about fan dissatisfaction, emphasizing the team's ongoing fight and positive outlook.
Boston College has three games left in the season, with a standout 2026 recruiting class ranked 35th by ESPN.

title: Apparently, Mass. had a ‘gustnado’ touch down Monday night — and more wind is coming
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: A 'gustnado' touched down in Massachusetts Monday, with wind speeds reaching up to 40 mph in Worcester.
The National Weather Service issued a high wind watch for Southern New England, expecting gusts of 55 to 65 mph.
Potential wind speeds could hit 70-75 mph near Provincetown, leading to possible tree damage and power outages.

title: Trio sought in alleged unprovoked Halloween attack at downtown T station
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: MBTA police seek public help identifying three suspects in a Halloween attack at State Street station.
The unprovoked physical assault occurred around 11 p.m. on October 31, at an Orange Line station.
Police released surveillance photos, asking those with information to contact them anonymously at 617-222-1050.
